title: Kareem Larrimore
text:
Kareem Maktrel Larrimore (born April 21, 1976 in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="California">California</a>) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) for the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>. He was drafted by the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> in the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft%23Round%20four">fourth round (109th overall)</a> of the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft">2000 NFL Draft</a>. He was also a member of the <a href="Dallas%20Desperados">Dallas Desperados</a>, <a href="Austin%20Wranglers">Austin Wranglers</a>, and <a href="Chicago%20Rush">Chicago Rush</a> of the <a href="Arena%20Football%20League%20%281987%E2%80%932008%29">Arena Football League</a> (AFL), and the <a href="Amarillo%20Dusters">Amarillo Dusters</a> (then of the <a href="Intense%20Football%20League">IFL</a>). He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="West%20Texas%20A%26amp%3BM%20Buffaloes%20football">West Texas A&M</a>.
Early years.
Larrimore attended <a href="Locke%20High%20School">Locke High School</a>, where he played only one year of <a href="American%20football">football</a> as a <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a> and returner. Because of poor grades, he spent one year after graduating earning his <a href="General%20Educational%20Development">GED</a>, before <a href="Walk-on%20%28sports%29">walking-on</a> at <a href="Cerritos%20College">Cerritos Junior College</a> where he was named junior college <a href="All-American">All-American</a> in his second year.
After the gang-related death of his brother, he transferred to <a href="West%20Texas%20A%26amp%3BM">West Texas A&M</a>, where he received <a href="NCAA%20Division%20II">Division II</a> <a href="All-America">All-America</a>n and All-<a href="Lone%20Star%20Conference">Lone Star Conference</a> honors. 
As a junior in 1998, he had 34 tackles (4 for loss), two interceptions (which he returned for 90 yards and one <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>) and 7 passes defensed, along with 20 kickoff returns for 532 yards (26.6 avg.) and one <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a> of 100 yards (tied a school record).
As a senior in 1999, he missed the season opener, but played the rest of the year and had 32 tackles, 5 interceptions (which he returned for 109 total yards and a 74-yard <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>) and 10 passes defensed, along with 15 kickoff returns for 318 yards. After the season, he played in the <a href="Blue-Gray%20Game">Blue-Gray All-Star Game</a>, where he returned a kickoff 99 yards for a <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>, which was a first in the 62-year history of the game. He also played in the <a href="Senior%20Bowl">Senior Bowl</a>.
Professional career.
Dallas Cowboys.
Larrimore was selected by the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> in the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft%23Round%20four">fourth round (109th overall)</a> of the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft">2000 NFL Draft</a>, after dropping because of character concerns and failing a marijuana test in the <a href="scouting%20combine">scouting combine</a>.
He impressed the team with his athletic ability from the beginning and moved ahead of fellow rookie draft picks <a href="Dwayne%20Goodrich">Dwayne Goodrich</a> and <a href="Mario%20Edwards">Mario Edwards</a>. Two weeks into <a href="Training%20camp%20%28National%20Football%20League%29">training camp</a>, he was named the starter at <a href="cornerback">left cornerback</a> in place of a retired <a href="Kevin%20Smith%20%28cornerback%29">Kevin Smith</a>. He was just the second rookie in franchise history (<a href="Ron%20Francis%20%28American%20football%29">Ron Francis</a> was the first) to start at <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a> in the season opener, but he struggled and was replaced with the more experienced <a href="Phillippi%20Sparks">Phillippi Sparks</a> after the fourth game of the season. The move didn't sit well with him and violations of team rules started to affect his standing with the team.
In <a href="2001%20NFL%20season">2001</a>, he was suspended for the final preseason game, the season opener and fined for missing curfew when the Cowboys traveled to <a href="Mexico%20City">Mexico City</a> to play the <a href="Oakland%20Raiders">Oakland Raiders</a> in the <a href="American%20Bowl">American Bowl</a>. He eventually was released on October 23, with reports later surfacing that he had been fined at least 11 other times for various reasons.
Larrimore played for the Cowboys for two seasons, appearing in 19 regular season games (15 in <a href="2000%20NFL%20season">2000</a>, four in <a href="2001%20NFL%20season">2001</a>) and starting in 6 games.
Dallas Desperados (AFL).
On May 21, <a href="2002%20Arena%20Football%20League%20season">2002</a>, he signed with the <a href="Dallas%20Desperados">Dallas Desperados</a> of the <a href="Arena%20Football%20League%20%281987%E2%80%932008%29">Arena Football League</a>, who were owned by <a href="Jerry%20Jones">Jerry Jones</a>, who also owned the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>. As a rookie, he played in nine games, earning the position as the team’s top kick returner and defensive specialist. He received <a href="Arena%20Football%20League">AFL</a> All-Rookie honors after finishing with 24.5 tackles, 5 passes defensed and one interception.
In <a href="2003%20Arena%20Football%20League%20season">2003</a>, knee and back injuries limited him to seven games, while spending time on the Reserve/Injured list three times. He recorded 26.5 tackles, 4 passes defensed, 2 interceptions and 27 kickoff returns for 476 yards (17.6 avg.).
Chicago Rush (AFL).
Larrimore was selected by the <a href="Austin%20Wranglers">Austin Wranglers</a> in the league's expansion draft, but was traded to the <a href="Chicago%20Rush">Chicago Rush</a> in exchange for Cedric Walker on October 15, <a href="2003%20Arena%20Football%20League%20season">2003</a>. He was waived on April 7, <a href="2004%20Arena%20Football%20League%20season">2004</a>, after registering 11 tackles, one interception, 21 kickoff returns for 485 yards and 2 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s.
Amarillo Dusters (IFL).
After three seasons in the <a href="Arena%20Football%20League%20%281987%E2%80%932008%29">Arena Football League</a>, Larrimore signed with the <a href="Amarillo%20Dusters">Amarillo Dusters</a> then of the <a href="Intense%20Football%20League">Intense Football League</a>, on May 28, 2004.
Inglewood Blackhawks (LCFL).
In 2009, he signed with the Inglewood Blackhawks of the LCFL West Semi pro league. He helped the team win the 2010 LCFL Championship.
